title: RL33972
content: Senate committees are required to adopt rules that align with Senate Rule XXVI, governing their organization and operation. These rules must not conflict with Senate rules and detail how the committee handles order and procedure. Committee rules demonstrate their approach to comity, fairness, power division, and responsibility allocation. For example, some committees require minority party presence when conducting business with less than a majority quorum. Senate committees must adopt their own set of rules, following the 1970 Legislative Reorganization Act, which requires committees to establish their procedures and have them printed in the Congressional Record by March 1 of the first year of a Congress. The Senate committees must establish their rules by March 1 of the first year of a Congress. While committee rules govern Senators' actions in committee proceedings, the Senate lacks enforcement power over committee conduct if a physical majority is present. There is no mechanism to enforce rules beyond those in the Senate's standing rules. This report analyzes Senate committees' approaches to their rules, comparing key features and specific procedural issues such as Meeting Day, Hearing Notice Requirements, Scheduling of Witnesses, and more. The report also reviews Senate rules for committees and how each committee handles these procedural issues. The report analyzes Senate committees' rules, including Proxy Voting, Polling, Nominations, Investigations, and Subpoenas. Committees have some flexibility in setting their rules, but must adhere to the specific requirements outlined in Rule XXVI of the Standing Rules of the Senate. Each committee must adopt rules published in the Congressional Record by March 1 of the first year of each Congress. Amendments to rules must also be published. Committees and subcommittees are authorized to meet and hold hearings when the Senate is in session or adjourned. Meetings must be announced at least one week in advance, with exceptions for "good cause." Special meetings can be called with a written request from three members to the chair. Committees and subcommittees can hold meetings and hearings during Senate sessions or when adjourned. Meetings must be announced at least a week in advance, with exceptions for "good cause." A written request to the chair can be made for a special meeting, which must be scheduled within three days and held within seven days. Meetings are generally open to the public, with specific rules for closed sessions. Media coverage may be allowed at the committee's discretion. Committees and subcommittees may adopt rules for media coverage and voting procedures. A quorum for business must be at least one-third of the membership, with a majority physically present for voting. Proxy voting may be allowed with prior notification to absent members. Senate committees have the power to investigate and issue subpoenas. The minority party can select witnesses to testify during hearings. Committees can report original bills and resolutions. Senate committees have the power to investigate, issue subpoenas, and report original bills and resolutions. A majority of the committee must be physically present for a measure to be reported, with a majority of those present required to order a measure reported. Committees are not required to issue a written report, but if they do, specific elements must be included. Committees in the 110th Congress do not use Monday or Friday for regular meetings, with most meetings scheduled on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, or Thursdays. Senate committees in the 110th Congress schedule regular meetings on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays. Committees must provide one week's notice for hearings and meetings, but shorter notice is allowed with good cause. Different committees have varying rules for determining what constitutes "good cause." The Senate committees in the 110th Congress have varying rules for scheduling hearings and meetings. Some committees require cooperation between the chair and ranking member to meet with less than a week's notice, while others give the responsibility to the chair alone or require consultation with the ranking minority member. The Senate committees in the 110th Congress have different rules for scheduling witnesses, with some allowing the minority to choose witnesses. The Finance Committee aims for a "balance of views" and lets each member designate witnesses. The Foreign Relations Committee allows the minority to request an equal number of witnesses. The Small Business and Entrepreneurship Committee permits an equal number of witnesses for both majority and minority, except for a single administration witness. The Budget Committee provides for equal numbers of witnesses for majority and minority, with the same exception for a single administration witness. The Ethics and Select Intelligence committees allow individuals to testify before the committee. The Senate committees have different rules for scheduling witnesses, with some allowing the minority to choose witnesses. Most committees reduce their quorum requirements to one or two Senators for receiving testimony at hearings. The "conduct of business" at a committee meeting typically involves actions like debating and voting on amendments. A member of the minority must be present for the conduct of business, and a majority of the committee must be physically present to report out a measure. During committee business meetings, minority attendance requirements vary. The Environment and Public Works Committee needs two minority members, while others like Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs only require one. The Veterans' Affairs Committee has provisions to prevent delays due to lack of minority members. Quorum requirements for other committees include one member from both majority and minority. The Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, Armed Services Committee, Judiciary Committee, and Indian Affairs Committee have specific quorum requirements. Senators must file first-degree amendments before committee meetings to allow for negotiation and preparation. Before the markup session begins, Members can draft second degree amendments to first degree amendments. Different Senate committees have varying notice requirements for submitting amendments before the markup. Proxy voting is permitted by most Senate committees. Most Senate committees allow proxy voting, with different requirements for execution. Proxies must be in writing for certain committees, while others allow transmission through various methods like telephone or personal instructions. Proxies cannot be used to count towards a quorum for reporting a measure or matter. The Budget Committee prohibits the use of proxies. The Budget Committee prohibits proxy voting during its annual markup of the budget resolution, and the Ethics Committee does not permit a Senator to vote by proxy on a motion to initiate an investigation. Polling is a method of taking a "vote" of the committee on a matter without the committee physically coming together. Polling can be used for internal housekeeping matters before the committee, such as questions concerning staffing or how the committee ought to proceed on a measure or matter. Only five committees have provisions for polling in their rules: Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry; Budget; Health, Education, Labor and Pensions; Homeland Security and Government Affairs; and Aging. Many Senate committees have rules for action on presidential nominations, with varying timetables for consideration. Committees like Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, Health, Education, Labor and Pensions, and Veterans' Affairs require a five-day layover before committee action, while others like Foreign Relations, Armed Services, and Intelligence have longer waiting periods. The Intelligence Committee, for example, mandates a fourteen-day delay before taking action on a nomination. The Senate committees have rules for action on presidential nominations, with varying timetables for consideration. Committees require nominees to testify under oath, and some have provisions for investigations with advance permission. The Select Intelligence Committee prohibits investigations unless requested by five committee members. The Senate committees have rules for authorizing investigations, with different requirements for approval. Some committees require full committee authorization, while others allow staff to initiate investigations with approval from the chair and ranking member. Six committees do not have specific rules for issuing subpoenas, but can still do so. The Senate committees have varying rules for issuing subpoenas. The Special Committee on Aging allows the chair to issue subpoenas alone, while seven other committees require approval from the ranking member. Four committees leave the decision to issue a subpoena to the full committee. Some committees have unique provisions not found in others. The Budget Committee limits the size and number of charts displayed during debate. The Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee only allows broadcasting with chair and ranking member approval. The Rules Committee chair and ranking member can approve rules, while the Small Business Committee allows any member to administer oaths. The Finance and Judiciary committees can end debate on measures, a unique power not found in other committees. The Foreign Relations Committee has a provision for its rules. The Foreign Relations Committee rules discourage formal parliamentary procedures, promoting resolution of issues before markup. The Veterans' Affairs and Environment committees guide federal facility naming. Banking Committee requires 67 cosponsors for Congressional Gold Medal consideration. Select Intelligence Committee reviews covert programs quarterly. Appropriations Committee empowers members managing bills. The Armed Services Committee requires executive branch response to measures referred to the committee. Homeland Security Committee evaluates regulatory impact of measures. Select Committee on Aging mandates majority approval for publishing investigative reports. Indian Affairs Committee urges financial disclosure. Energy and Natural Resources Committee allows any Member to introduce measures. The Energy and Natural Resources Committee allows any Member to place a measure on the agenda with one week notice. The Judiciary Committee permits any member to delay consideration of agenda items for one week. The Select Committee on Ethics lets any member postpone discussion until a majority is present.
